Award.AbstractNarration:
Algebraic curves are subsets of the plane defined by the vanishing of a polynomial of two variables. They are important in geometry, physics and number theory. Moduli spaces of curves parametrize all curves of a given topological type. This type is classified by a whole number called the genus of the curve. Some questions about moduli spaces of curves of all genera can be resolved by answering the the questions in genus zero and one. This proposal focuses on understanding the interaction between the topology of moduli spaces of curves, especially in genus one and the "arithmetic symmetries" of topological invariants of the moduli spaces. Resolving such basic questions is important in advancing our understanding of whole numbers and of the topological symmetries of zero sets of polynomials.

The overall goal of this project is to understand motivic aspects of completions of fundamental groups and path torsors of moduli spaces of curves in all genera $\ge 0$. Although motivic structures on path torsors of moduli spaces of genus 0 curves are reasonably well understood (work of Deligne-Goncharov and Brown), fundamental problems remain, such as determining the Zariski closure of the image of the absolute Galois group in the automorphism group of the unipotent fundamental group of the thrice punctured projective line (a de~Rham version of the Grothendieck-Teichmuller program), and understanding why and how classical cusp forms impose relations in the associated graded of its depth filtration. Much of the PI's attention will be focused on the genus one case as it is the most central and also because of its connection to the theory of classical modular forms. It influences the genus 0 case by degeneration to the nodal cubic and should help explain why modular forms impose conditions on the Galois action on the unipotent fundamental group of the thrice punctured projective line. The higher genus cases can be reduced to the genus zero and one cases by results in topology that go back to Harer. This project will also clarify Manin's work on iterated Shimura integrals and arithmetic aspects of the elliptic KZB equation, which arose in physics, but plays a special role in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An algebraic curve C is defined by a polynomial equation f(x,y) = 0. For example, C may be the curve x3 + y2 + 1 = 0. The collection of solutions to f(x,y) = 0, where x and y are complex numbers, forms a topological surface X. When the coefficients of f(x,y) are whole numbers, the topological properties of this surface control the solutions to f(x,y), where x and y are whole numbers or fractions. This connection is mysterious and not well understood. One tool for understanding this relationship is to use calculus to associate numbers to the algebraic curve C by integrating 1-forms associated to f(x,y) over loops in the associated topological surface X. In the example above, one integrates dx/y and xdx/y over loops in the associated surface. These numbers are examples of periods. Conjecturally, the periods associated to C control its arithmetic properties such as the number of whole number solutions to f(x,y) = 0. This project established fundamental properties of these and more general periods associated to two important classes of algebraic curves: elliptic curves and modular curves. In particular, it makes fundamental contributions to the "Galois theory of periods".


Another contribution of this project was to relate certain topological operations on the surface X to the arithmetic properties of the curve C. These topological operations are the Goldman bracket and the Turaev cobracket. Their definition, inspired by physics, is very geometric and has no apparent connection to arithmetic properties of the curve C. One of the main outcomes of this research was to show that these operations have arithmetic significance and that they impose conditions on the periods of C and thus its arithmetic properties as well.


This work has potential applications to particle physics, such as the experiments conducted in the particle accelerator at CERN, Geneva. Feynman amplitudes are numbers that are used to predict the interactions of particles that are colliding at high energy. They are periods of algebraic curves or their higher dimensional generalizations and are often iterated integrals associated to modular and/or elliptic curves of the kind studied in this project. One approach to computing these integrals, pioneered by Francis Brown, is to exploit the arithmetic symmetries of these integrals (via the "Galois theory of periods") to reduce them to simpler integrals.


During the period of the grant, the PI has had 4 PhD students graduate (three in 2015 and one in 2018). Two more will graduate in 2020. In addition, the PI has had one undergraduate research student who is now pursuing a PhD in mathematics at Columbia University.
